image.altText: Steven Bradbury

image.altText: Tasmanian home-owner Louise Elliott works at her laptop.

image.altText: Oodnadatta sign

image.altText: A woman swims in the water next to a whale.

items.synopsis: A Byron Bay couple's bucket list is shorter after their "once in a lifetime" swim with a juvenile humpback.

image.altText: Man in scrubs talks to man in dental chair.

items.synopsis: Phasing out cash has serious implications for privacy, safety and financial exclusion among marginalised communities.

image.altText: A man sitting at a desk with his hands clasped together

image.altText: Don and Gail, dressed in warm jackets, smile as they stand in front of the sea on a sunny day.

image.altText: A young girl sits in a booster seat in the rear seat of a car.

title.children: When is it safe for a child to sit in the front seat? Kidsafe urges parents to rethink child restraints

image.altText: A sad fisherman at a protest

image.altText: A black-and-white photo of a young army soldier in the 1970s.

items.synopsis: Lieutenant Colonel Harry Smith SG MC, the most esteemed commander of Australia's bloodiest battle of the Vietnam War, has died in his Buderim home on Queensland's Sunshine Coast.

title.children: Legendary Long Tan veteran Lieutenant Colonel Harry Smith dies, aged 90

image.altText: Composite of a black and white photo of a man holding a guitar with an older man to his right and older woman to his left.

items.synopsis: Lisa Colnan remembers her second cousin, Crispin Dye, as a lovely and creative soul. But just before Christmas 1993, the 41-year-old musician and record company manager was fatally bashed in a laneway behind the Kinsela's pub in Sydney.

title.children: A love letter to Crispin Dye: Family and friends fight for justice

image.altText: A blond woman waves, she is wearing a red scarf around her neck.

items.synopsis: The Australian government drops a case against actor Amber Heard, after her former partner Johnny Depp claimed she lied over the illegal importation of her two dogs, Pistol and Boo, in 2015.

title.children: Australia drops perjury case against Amber Heard over importation of Pistol and Boo

image.altText: A woman in a bright red sweater and blue jeans texts on her smartphone

items.synopsis: All you wanted was to sell your sofa online. So why are so many "buyers" suddenly insisting on using your PayID? Cassandra Cross explains how you can avoid falling prey to the latest scam.

title.children: Inside the PayID scam that's netted at least $260,000 from Australians online

image.altText: A young woman sits up on a stretcher

items.synopsis: A 23-year-old bank teller caught up in a siege inspired the psychological term Stockholm syndrome. But 50 years later, experts say Kristin's story is totally misunderstood.

title.children: 'I know my story. I know my truth': The woman behind Stockholm Syndrome says it's all a lie

image.altText: A collection a photos of pregnant women and newborn babies.

items.synopsis: Telehealth is revolutionising medicine in remote areas, but one obstetrician says entrusting the delivery of a baby to "pure luck" in Australia during 2023 "isn't good enough".

title.children: No privacy, no pain relief and no specialist: Mothers traumatised by unplanned telehealth births

image.altText: A cable car which has come partially off it's cable in Pakistan.

items.synopsis: Rescuers work into the night to retrieve stranded passengers hanging from a single cable some 275 metres in the air in Pakistan.

title.children: Here's how the morning school run became a tense race against time to rescue seven Pakistani schoolchildren

image.altText: Woolworths sign

items.synopsis: Grocery giant Woolworths says high inflation has seen its annual profit rise to $1.62 billion, and warns food inflation is set to continue. The ASX and Australian dollar gain thanks to stronger commodity prices.

title.children: Woolworths reports $1.62b profit on higher prices, ASX and Australian dollar driven higher by iron ore prices

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government has announced a review of competition policy to make it more difficult for big companies to take over smaller firms. Assistant Minister for Competition Andrew Leigh says Australia's productivity growth has slowed over the past decade and reduced competition has contributed. The review will look at competition laws, policies and institutions and a competition task force has been established in Treasury. The review will look at: Proposals put forward by the Australian      Competition and Consumer Commission around merger reform, as well as other      competition law issues Options for coordinated reform with states      and territories, to be progressed through the Council on Federal Financial      Relations Non-compete and related clauses that      restrict workers from shifting to a better-paying job Providing advice on competition issues      raised by new technologies, the net zero transformation and growth in the      care economy Former ACCC chair Rod Sims and current ACCC chair Gina Cass-Gottleib have called for stronger laws to stop mergers that entrench market power. "We always need to get the balance right on merger reform," said Mr Leigh. "The ACCC's proposals ... are serious proposals deserving of careful scrutiny"
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Review of competition policy

children.content: The federal government has announced a review of competition policy to make it more difficult for big companies to take over smaller firms.
Assistant Minister for Competition
Andrew Leigh
says Australia's productivity growth has slowed over the past decade and reduced competition has contributed.
The review will look at competition laws, policies and institutions and a competition task force has been established in Treasury.
The review will look at:
Proposals put forward by the Australian      Competition and Consumer Commission around merger reform, as well as other      competition law issues
Options for coordinated reform with states      and territories, to be progressed through the Council on Federal Financial      Relations
Non-compete and related clauses that      restrict workers from shifting to a better-paying job
Providing advice on competition issues      raised by new technologies, the net zero transformation and growth in the      care economy
Former ACCC chair Rod Sims and current ACCC chair Gina Cass-Gottleib have called for stronger laws to stop mergers that entrench market power.
"We always need to get the balance right on merger reform," said Mr Leigh.
"The ACCC's proposals ... are serious proposals deserving of careful scrutiny"

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Woolworths boss Brad Banducci is warning of a tough consumer environment, but he hopes slowing inflation may mean lower supermarket prices. The supermarket giant posted a $1.62 billion profit for 2023. "Looking ahead to FY24, we expect food inflation in Australia and New Zealand to continue to moderate but will likely remain elevated in some packaged categories," Mr Banducci said. The supermarket chain is seeing higher rates of theft amid the high cost of living. Mr Banducci has told ABC senior business correspondent Peter Ryan that shoplifting has increased and organised gangs are stealing goods to resell.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Woolworths CEO says organised gangs stealing products

children.content: Woolworths boss Brad Banducci is warning of a tough consumer environment, but he hopes slowing inflation may mean lower supermarket prices.
The supermarket giant posted a $1.62 billion profit for 2023.
"Looking ahead to FY24, we expect food inflation in Australia and New Zealand to continue to moderate but will likely remain elevated in some packaged categories," Mr Banducci said.
The supermarket chain is seeing higher rates of theft amid the high cost of living.
Mr Banducci has told ABC senior business correspondent Peter Ryan that shoplifting has increased and organised gangs are stealing goods to resell.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has shrugged off a slow start and is trading up 0.7 per cent at midday. The ASX 200 is being driven by consumer stocks, banks, and miners after iron ore prices surged overnight. Technology stocks and healthcare firms are taking a hit. Woolworths is up 5.1 per cent after its posted a rise in profit. Domino's Pizza has surged despite a big fall in profit because it is cutting 200 jobs and restructuring. Here are the top movers: IDP Education: +9.7 per cent to $25.53 Monadelphous: +9.4 per cent to $14.74 Domino's Pizza: +8.1 per cent to $51.92 WiseTech Global: -19.2 per cent to $70 Nanosonics: -9.2 per cent to $4.08 Illuka Resources: -7.4 per cent to $4.08
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian share market makes tracks

children.content: The Australian share market has shrugged off a slow start and is trading up 0.7 per cent at midday.
The ASX 200 is being driven by consumer stocks, banks, and miners after iron ore prices surged overnight.
Technology stocks and healthcare firms are taking a hit.
Woolworths is up 5.1 per cent after its posted a rise in profit.
Domino's Pizza has surged despite a big fall in profit because it is cutting 200 jobs and restructuring.
Here are the top movers:
IDP Education: +9.7 per cent to $25.53
Monadelphous: +9.4 per cent to $14.74
Domino's Pizza: +8.1 per cent to $51.92
WiseTech Global: -19.2 per cent to $70
Nanosonics: -9.2 per cent to $4.08
Illuka Resources: -7.4 per cent to $4.08

image.altText: A middle-aged couple on a paddleboat in a lake, shrouded in an orange haze of bushfire smoke.

items.synopsis: Canada’s record-breaking wildfires are significantly worse because of climate change, according to a rapid analysis by a leading team of scientists.

title.children: 'It's going to get worse': Warnings for Australian summer after study shows climate change worsened Canada's wildfires
